pullRequest.body:
In this PR we provide a proof of the Jacobson-Noether theorem following [this blog](https://ysharifi.wordpress.com/2011/09/30/the-jacobson-noether-theorem/)

Co-authored by: Filippo A. E. Nuccio @faenuccio
Co-authored by: Wanyi He @Blackfeather007
Co-authored by: Huanyu Zheng @Yu-Misaka
Co-authored by: Yi Yuan @yuanyi-350
Co-authored by: Weichen Jiao @AlbertJ-314
Co-authored by: Sihan Wu @Old-Turtledove
Co-authored by: @FR-vdash-bot

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:



If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

bot fix style
There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?

> There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?

I think indeed we've tried using [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) for Fact 2 in the blog. But like you said, we need to either extend purely inseparable to non-commutative case or figure out how to define `k(\alpha)` in the notation of that blog (the difficulty here is that `IntermediateField.adjoin` demands a field over `k(\alpha)`, which isn't easy to find). This is surely an interesting idea.
I think instead of `open Classical`, the right thing to do is use tactic `Classical` whenever you need it

Do you think this is a better statement of the result?
```lean
import Mathlib.RingTheory.Algebraic
import Mathlib.FieldTheory.Separable

example {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D]
    [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
    (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
    (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
    âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
  sorry
```
~Note that this is not necessary correct; I haven't assume `k` is the center of `D`.~ The center assumption is needed, otherwise a couhterexample is `D` a (commutative) purely inseparable extension of `k`. ~But what about this: change the assumption to `Subalgebra.center k D â‰  âŠ¤` and the result to `âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subalgebra.center k D âˆ§ IsSeparable k x`?~

The advantage of this statement is that now `k` and `D` are both types, while your approach `k` is a subring, then converted to a type.

> Do you think this is a better statement of the result?
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.RingTheory.Algebraic
> import Mathlib.FieldTheory.Separable
> 
> example {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D]
>     [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
>     (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
>     (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
>   sorry
> ```
> 
> ~Note that this is not necessary correct; I haven't assume `k` is the center of `D`.~ The center assumption is needed, otherwise a couhterexample is `D` a (commutative) purely inseparable extension of `k`. But what about this: change the assumption to `Subalgebra.center k D â‰  âŠ¤` and the result to `âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subalgebra.center k D âˆ§ IsSeparable k x`?
> 
> The advantage of this statement is that now `k` and `D` are both types, while your approach `k` is a subring, then converted to a type.

Then probly the assumption `hneq` is redundant since if âŠ¥ = âŠ¤ then not in âŠ¥ is in the empty set
Also it's probly not the best idea to use `rename_i`

> Do you think this is a better statement of the result?
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.RingTheory.Algebraic
> import Mathlib.FieldTheory.Separable
> 
> example {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D]
>     [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
>     (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
>     (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
>   sorry
> ```
> 
> ~Note that this is not necessary correct; I haven't assume `k` is the center of `D`.~ The center assumption is needed, otherwise a couhterexample is `D` a (commutative) purely inseparable extension of `k`. But what about this: change the assumption to `Subalgebra.center k D â‰  âŠ¤` and the result to `âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subalgebra.center k D âˆ§ IsSeparable k x`?
> 
> The advantage of this statement is that now `k` and `D` are both types, while your approach `k` is a subring, then converted to a type.

This is probably a good point; I would suggest that we try to keep *both* versions, provided the proof of the second is very very short using the first one.

@Whysoserioushah I have seen your commit e86ef6420621ebc0b9f836de5958c2ee15e9691e and that you have removed some comment I made. It is normally a good habit to only leave the authors of one branch to commit/push, and to add suggestions that they can point-by-point decide to accept or reject. By the way, do you have a Zulip account, so that we can communicate more directly there (which is certainly more appropriate than here)? Thanks!

OK, no problem: and thanks for the zulip name! Concerning the group chat, our hope is that everybody will be a regular active Zulip user, and private groups go a bit against this philosophy. I normally use DM with groups that I mentor, as in this case, but then the public chat is preferable.

> > There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?
> 
> I think indeed we've tried using [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) for Fact 2 in the blog. But like you said, we need to either extend purely inseparable to non-commutative case or figure out how to define `k(\alpha)` in the notation of that blog (the difficulty here is that `IntermediateField.adjoin` demands a field over `k(\alpha)`, which isn't easy to find). This is surely an interesting idea.

The newest version of mathlib supports purely inseparable for non-commutative rings. You can try it out.

> > > There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?
> > 
> > 
> > I think indeed we've tried using [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) for Fact 2 in the blog. But like you said, we need to either extend purely inseparable to non-commutative case or figure out how to define `k(\alpha)` in the notation of that blog (the difficulty here is that `IntermediateField.adjoin` demands a field over `k(\alpha)`, which isn't easy to find). This is surely an interesting idea.
> 
> The newest version of mathlib supports purely inseparable for non-commutative rings. You can try it out.

Thanks for the PR! I've already merged recent master into this branch. We'll look into it.

> > I think this is not needed, since the newly added instance has `{R : Type*}` which will override the existing `R`.
> 
> Ah, you mean that in the new instance we do not want the `Comm` assumption on `R`?

I haven't checked the mathematics, but in the following code
```lean
variable [CommRing R]
variable (R)

...

instance {R : Type*} [Ring R] : ...
```
the code `instance {R : Type*} [Ring R]` will introduce a new `R` which is different from the existing `R` (you can check the info panel), so the original `[CommRing R]` is not carried over.

> I wasn't able to fill in the two `sorry` in `temp_exists_pow_mem_center_ofInseparable`, line 209. These two `sorry` are used to show that `Algebra.adjoin k {a}` (`k(a)` in the notation of the blog) is purely separable over `k`. The difficulties here are to prove `k(a)` is integral over `k`, and resolve the image of `algebraMap`.

I don't think you need to tackle `Algebra.adjoin` things here, since they are already solved in separable/purely inseparable APIs. You may start with the following code:
```lean
import Mathlib.FieldTheory.PurelyInseparable

open LinearMap in
theorem test1
    {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D] [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
    (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
    (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
    âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
  classical
  obtain âŸ¨q, _âŸ© := ExpChar.exists k
  by_contra! H
  have h1 : IsPurelyInseparable k D :=
    âŸ¨Algebra.IsAlgebraic.isIntegral, fun x â†¦ not_imp_not.1 (H x)âŸ©
  rw [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem k q] at h1
  sorry
```
First you can conclude `IsPurelyInseparable k D` just from the definition of purely inseparable in mathlib. Then you use `isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem` to conclude that every element of `D` can be powered into `k`.

> > I wasn't able to fill in the two `sorry` in `temp_exists_pow_mem_center_ofInseparable`, line 209. These two `sorry` are used to show that `Algebra.adjoin k {a}` (`k(a)` in the notation of the blog) is purely separable over `k`. The difficulties here are to prove `k(a)` is integral over `k`, and resolve the image of `algebraMap`.
> 
> I don't think you need to tackle `Algebra.adjoin` things here, since they are already solved in separable/purely inseparable APIs. You may start with the following code:
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.FieldTheory.PurelyInseparable
> 
> open LinearMap in
> theorem test1
>     {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D] [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
>     (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
>     (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
>   classical
>   obtain âŸ¨q, _âŸ© := ExpChar.exists k
>   by_contra! H
>   have h1 : IsPurelyInseparable k D :=
>     âŸ¨Algebra.IsAlgebraic.isIntegral, fun x â†¦ not_imp_not.1 (H x)âŸ©
>   rw [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem k q] at h1
>   sorry
> ```
> 
> First you can conclude `IsPurelyInseparable k D` just from the definition of purely inseparable in mathlib. Then you use `isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem` to conclude that every element of `D` can be powered into `k`.

Indeed, I can bypass `Algebra.adjoin`, thanks! I've finished migration of the first statement, and will try out the second statement.

I added in namespace `canary` some trials inspired by @faenuccio regarding translation between two statements. Now the only thing remains is proving `IsSeparable L x` from `IsSeparable (center D) x` given `L â‰ƒ+* (center D)`. I wonder if we have any method in Lean to "view isomorphic structures as the same thing" as we sometimes do in math.

> Now the only thing remains is proving `IsSeparable L x` from `IsSeparable (center D) x` given `L â‰ƒ+* (center D)`. I wonder if we have any method in Lean to "view isomorphic structures as the same thing" as we sometimes do in math.

Lean is very explicit on such things (compared to human doing math, which will occasionally cause subtle errors). Maybe you can try [IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv).

Oh, it requires fields... maybe we should generalize that result first...

> > Now the only thing remains is proving `IsSeparable L x` from `IsSeparable (center D) x` given `L â‰ƒ+* (center D)`. I wonder if we have any method in Lean to "view isomorphic structures as the same thing" as we sometimes do in math.
> 
> Lean is very explicit on such things (compared to human doing math, which will occasionally cause subtle errors). Maybe you can try [IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv).
> 
> Oh, it requires fields... maybe we should generalize that result first...

Good idea! I found that at least in our application here, we can generalize [IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv) via generalizing [IsSeparable.tower_top](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#IsSeparable.tower_top), which can be done by removing commutativity in [minpoly.dvd_map_of_isScalarTower](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Minpoly/Field.html#minpoly.dvd_map_of_isScalarTower). I've wrote a sketch `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv'` in namespace `canary`.

> we can generalize [IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv) via generalizing [IsSeparable.tower_top](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.html#IsSeparable.tower_top), which can be done by removing commutativity in [minpoly.dvd_map_of_isScalarTower](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Minpoly/Field.html#minpoly.dvd_map_of_isScalarTower).

You are welcomed to submit a separate PR for generalizing these.

Thanks! Though I still have some questions before that. I've moved related codes to namespace `separable_canary`. The first question is that I want to have an instance `Algebra Aâ‚‚ Bâ‚` in line 200, but if I switch `def` to `instance`, it immediately yields error `cannot find synthesization order for instance @instAlgebra`. ~~The second is that I want `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv'` and `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv''` to use variables like `Aâ‚ Bâ‚ Aâ‚‚ Bâ‚‚` defined at the beginning of the namespace, but once I omit them in the statement, the infer system seems to be confused~~. How can I solve these?

(the commit seems messy now, but once the instance is fixed, we can remove condition `hl` in `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equivâ‚€`, `he` in `IsSeparable.of_equiv` (this will then close our original problem of translating statements), and `hc` in `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv''`. Plus `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equivâ‚€` will no longer be needed.)

If it's me, I'll write the instance `Algebra Aâ‚‚ Bâ‚` into the proof of `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv` instead of outside (because it only uses inside this proof, put it outside will confuse typeclass inferencing system). Like this:
```lean
lemma IsSeparable.of_equiv_equivâ‚€ ... ... :=
  ......
  letI : Algebra Aâ‚‚ Bâ‚ := {
    ......
  }
  ...
```
Maybe you can check the original proof https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/4e3fd1ae9518ed2894bfc00592c81a3ee2b6180e/Mathlib/FieldTheory/Separable.lean#L687-L697 the line 689 defines the instance `Algebra Aâ‚‚ Bâ‚`.

Greetings! Sorry I have been stuck here for a while and I didn't manage to advance. The problem now is to prove ```(algebraMap L D).comp â†‘equiv.symm = algebraMap { x // x âˆˆ center D } D```, where ```equiv``` is equivalence ```L â‰ƒ+* { x // x âˆˆ center D }```. Can any one help? Thanks a lot in advance!
(Plus, in fact I don't quite understand why we need the diagram to be commutative in ```IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv```::>_<::)

@acmepjz I think this might be a good moment to share the proof you showed me in the DM of Sep14th of your `test1` to prove the `example` on ll. 198 of `Mathlib\FieldTheory\JacobsonNoether.lean`, no? I can do this, but since this is your code, I'd rather leave it to you ðŸ˜„

> I think this might be a good moment to share the proof you showed me in the DM of Sep14th of your `test1` to prove the `example` on ll. 198 of `Mathlib\FieldTheory\JacobsonNoether.lean`, no? I can do this, but since this is your code, I'd rather leave it to you ðŸ˜„

Sure, but my proof is in the other direction
```lean
import Mathlib.FieldTheory.PurelyInseparable

open LinearMap in
theorem test1
    {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D] [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
    (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
    (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
    âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
  -- omitted for now
  sorry

instance {R : Type*} [Ring R] : Algebra (Subring.center R) R where
  toFun := Subtype.val
  map_one' := rfl
  map_mul' _ _ := rfl
  map_zero' := rfl
  map_add' _ _ := rfl
  commutes' r x := (Subring.mem_center_iff.1 r.2 x).symm
  smul_def' _ _ := rfl

theorem test2 {D : Type*} [DivisionRing D]
    [Algebra.IsAlgebraic (Subring.center D) D]
    (hneq : Subring.center D â‰  âŠ¤) :
    âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subring.center D âˆ§ IsSeparable (Subring.center D) x := by
  have := test1 (k := Subring.center D) (D := D) ?_ ?_
  Â· obtain âŸ¨x, hx, hsepâŸ© := this
    exact âŸ¨x, by simpa using (show x âˆ‰ Set.range Subtype.val from hx), hsepâŸ©
  Â· ext x
    change x âˆˆ Subring.center D â†” x âˆˆ Set.range Subtype.val
    simp
  Â· contrapose! hneq
    apply SetLike.coe_injective
    simpa using (show Set.range Subtype.val = âŠ¤ from congr(SetLike.coe $(hneq)))
```
But I think the author asks for `test2 -> test1`, which I'm not think of yet.

Note that my proof does not use `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv`.

> in fact I don't quite understand why we need the diagram to be commutative in `IsSeparable.of_equiv_equiv`

Maybe you can check its proof to see what will happen without the condition that the diagram is commutative.

> The problem now is to prove `(algebraMap L D).comp â†‘equiv.symm = algebraMap { x // x âˆˆ center D } D`, where `equiv` is equivalence `L â‰ƒ+* { x // x âˆˆ center D }`.

Can you try `by ext; rfl` or `by ext; simp`?

> > The problem now is to prove `(algebraMap L D).comp â†‘equiv.symm = algebraMap { x // x âˆˆ center D } D`, where `equiv` is equivalence `L â‰ƒ+* { x // x âˆˆ center D }`.
> 
> Can you try `by ext; rfl` or `by ext; simp`?

I proved both, and I also tried to expand a bit the definitions, with no result. Probably the suggestion of using the `Subalgebra.equivOfEq` is the right one, haven't checked it.

> > I think this might be a good moment to share the proof you showed me in the DM of Sep14th of your `test1` to prove the `example` on ll. 198 of `Mathlib\FieldTheory\JacobsonNoether.lean`, no? I can do this, but since this is your code, I'd rather leave it to you ðŸ˜„

>

> 
> open LinearMap in
> theorem test1
>     {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D] [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
>     (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
>     (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
>   -- omitted for now
>   sorry
> 
> instance {R : Type*} [Ring R] : Algebra (Subring.center R) R where
>   toFun := Subtype.val
>   map_one' := rfl
>   map_mul' _ _ := rfl
>   map_zero' := rfl
>   map_add' _ _ := rfl
>   commutes' r x := (Subring.mem_center_iff.1 r.2 x).symm
>   smul_def' _ _ := rfl
> 
> theorem test2 {D : Type*} [DivisionRing D]
>     [Algebra.IsAlgebraic (Subring.center D) D]
>     (hneq : Subring.center D â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subring.center D âˆ§ IsSeparable (Subring.center D) x := by
>   have := test1 (k := Subring.center D) (D := D) ?_ ?_
>   Â· obtain âŸ¨x, hx, hsepâŸ© := this
>     exact âŸ¨x, by simpa using (show x âˆ‰ Set.range Subtype.val from hx), hsepâŸ©
>   Â· ext x
>     change x âˆˆ Subring.center D â†” x âˆˆ Set.range Subtype.val
>     simp
>   Â· contrapose! hneq
>     apply SetLike.coe_injective
>     simpa using (show Set.range Subtype.val = âŠ¤ from congr(SetLike.coe $(hneq)))
> ```
> 
> But I think the author asks for `test2 -> test1`, which I'm not think of yet.

Ah right! Well, they might be happy to see a proof of `test1` directly and actually all of the code you gave me, by now...ðŸ˜„
Thanks all for your kind help @faenuccio @acmepjz! I sincerely appreciate that. Also, @FR-vdash-bot managed to close the second statement in a rather neat way as the above commit suggests.

@faenuccio Greetings! Thanks, I've implemented all suggestions
(btw would you please help review #17147? thanks!

Greetings! Thanks for your suggestions! 
I think I've already addressed all of them, please let me know if I missed anything

@faenuccio Greetings! Thanks for your review, and I've implemented most of the comments.
For `âˆƒ n > 0, ...`, I changed it to `âˆƒ n, (0 < n) âˆ§ ...` since `âˆƒ 0 < n` doesn't seem to work. I also left `hb` unchanged because both parts of it are used. In addition, I changed the "finite dimensional" in JN's annotation to "algebraic" since they might not be equivalent in my view. But please tell me if I'm wrong or I mistook anything.
Sorry I didn't notice the change of `open Classical` in @Blackfeather007 's commit. It is indeed better to be placed behind.

This might not be a good commit and a recompilation is needed.
1. I moved `center_char_iff` to Algebra/CharP/Subring, this is a proof for characteristic of a division ring is equal to its center's. The reason for such move is that `subring` in Algebra/CharP/Subring gives a weaker but more general statement.
2. The instance `Algebra k D` is moved to Algebra/Algebra/Basic. I don't have any convincing argument in favour of this move - I just can't find other related file that works.

> I think this is not needed, since the newly added instance has `{R : Type*}` which will override the existing `R`. 

Ah, you mean that in the new instance we do not want the `Comm`  assumption on  `R`?

Greetings! In this commit, I added section `purelyInsep`, in which I tried to switch to `ExpChar` and purely inseparable. By such, `JacobsonNoether_charZero` and `JacobsonNoether_charP` are unified. 
~~However, I wasn't able to fill in the two `sorry` in `temp_exists_pow_mem_center_ofInseparable`, line 209. These two `sorry` are used to show that `Algebra.adjoin k {a}` (`k(a)` in the notation of the blog) is purely separable over `k`. The difficulties here are to prove `k(a)` is integral over `k`, and resolve the image of `algebraMap`.~~ Plus, I noticed that the new instance in LinearMaps seems to be slow.
I left several comments, and I have not started a proper revision of the main file `JacobsonNoether.lean`. Please address them all, and I will then embark in the final review.
OK, I have added more comments and stopped short of the two proofs of JN. I will also have a look at #17147 once this PR will get merged (but please re-ping me if I forget).
Boarding my flight now, but I'll continue the review later
I have posted more comments for the first proof of JN: please implement them and then I'll resume the review.

Maybe you can use [LinearMap.mulLeft](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Bilinear.html#LinearMap.mulLeft) for `f`, [LinearMap.mulRight](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Bilinear.html#LinearMap.mulRight) for `g`, [LinearMap.commute_mulLeft_right](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/Algebra/Bilinear.html#LinearMap.commute_mulLeft_right) for they commutes, etc. etc.
Good idea, implemented, thanks!
Maybe you can just write `private def Î´ (a : D) : D â†’â‚—[k] D := f - g`. Note that `D â†’â‚—[k] D` is a ring, which is known by mathlib.
implemented

Do you really need this instance? In my opinion this `instance` is not working with instance inferring system (only works as a `theorem`), since from the conclusion `CharP (M â†’â‚—[R] M) p` it cannot says `hreduction` must be satisfied.
converted to `theorem`. Do you think it still worth keeping?

To add something to @acmepjz 's comment (that is perfectly appropriate): if you type
```lean
#lint
```
at the end of your file (with `char_eq_if` still marked as `instance`) you get
```
-- Found 1 error in 4 declarations (plus 62 automatically generated ones) in the current file with 15 linters

/- The `impossibleInstance` linter reports:
SOME INSTANCES HAVE ARGUMENTS THAT ARE IMPOSSIBLE TO INFER
These are arguments that are not instance-implicit and do not appear in
another instance-implicit argument or the return type. -/
#check @char_eq_if /- argument 8 hreduction : âˆƒ x, âˆ€ (r : R), r â€¢ x = 0 â†’ r = 0 -/
```
This error tells you that type-class inference is _uncapable_ of finding `hreduction` automatically and so the system does not even accept `char_eq_if` as an `instance`. The point here is that if there are assumptions in your declaration (like `hreduction`), for it to be an `instance` it is needed that these assumptions are found _automatically_. By this, we mean that they must themselves be part of the automatic type-search tree, while if they are simply variables the system will fail to find them. The only solution would be to create a `class hreduction` whose terms are types satisfying it, and requiring at the beginning that `R` is of this class (if makes no sense here, I am just trying to explain the whole situation). As a rule-of-thumb, you can think that (apart from type variables) all variables of a class/instance must themselves be classes.

> converted to `theorem`. Do you think it still worth keeping?

Well, why not?

> To add something to @acmepjz 's comment (that is perfectly appropriate): if you type
> 
> ```lean
> #lint
> ```
> 
> at the end of your file (with `char_eq_if` still marked as `instance`) you get
> 
> ```
> -- Found 1 error in 4 declarations (plus 62 automatically generated ones) in the current file with 15 linters
> 
> /- The `impossibleInstance` linter reports:
> SOME INSTANCES HAVE ARGUMENTS THAT ARE IMPOSSIBLE TO INFER
> These are arguments that are not instance-implicit and do not appear in
> another instance-implicit argument or the return type. -/
> #check @char_eq_if /- argument 8 hreduction : âˆƒ x, âˆ€ (r : R), r â€¢ x = 0 â†’ r = 0 -/
> ```
> 
> This error tells you that type-class inference is _uncapable_ of finding `hreduction` automatically and so the system does not even accept `char_eq_if` as an `instance`. The point here is that if there are assumptions in your declaration (like `hreduction`), for it to be an `instance` it is needed that these assumptions are found _automatically_. By this, we mean that they must themselves be part of the automatic type-search tree, while if they are simply variables the system will fail to find them. The only solution would be to create a `class hreduction` whose terms are types satisfying it, and requiring at the beginning that `R` is of this class (if makes no sense here, I am just trying to explain the whole situation). As a rule-of-thumb, you can think that (apart from type variables) all variables of a class/instance must themselves be classes.

Thanks for the explanation! I noticed before in previous Github Action that there are lint mathlib errors but I didn't know what it was. Now it's clear, thanks again!

> > converted to `theorem`. Do you think it still worth keeping?
> 
> Well, why not?

I was thinking that, it seems possible to deduce similar result via `charP_of_injective_ringHom`. For instance, we can define map `R â†’ (M â†’â‚—[R] M)` as `r â†¦ (fun (x : M) â†¦ r â€¢ x)`. If this map is injective, then we are done. 
And its injectivity is equivalent to `âˆ€ x : M, âˆ€ r : R, r â€¢ x = 0 â†’ r = 0`, which is slightly more strict than `hreduction : âˆƒ x : M, âˆ€ r : R, r â€¢ x = 0 â†’ r = 0`. Plus, one might also need `R` to be a ring to prove injectivity. Hence, I think that `char_eq_if` could be more general (and its proof shorter), but I'm not sure if it is significant enough to be in mathlib.
Well, all in all I agree that this is then probably not needed, you can simply apply `charP_of_injective_ringHom`.

I think you can use [charP_of_injective_ringHom](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Algebra/CharP/Algebra.html#charP_of_injective_ringHom) (after deducing that `Subring.center D` is of characteristic p). In this way the proof becomes a one-liner.
Wow, it works, thanks!
I think it's better to use `ExpChar` instead, by this way the char 0 and char p proof can probably be unified.

Sorry I didn't catch it, why char 0 and char p can be unified through `ExpChar`? I tried to change the statement of `JacobsonNoether_charZero` and `JacobsonNoether_charP` into `ExpChar`. But when I attempted to use them in `Jacobson_Noether`, I still need `cases` to split the condition and apply two lemmas accordingly. (Or do you mean that with `ExpChar`, we'll no longer need separate `JacobsonNoether_charZero` and `JacobsonNoether_charP`?)

I mean you don't need to separate the proof of `JacobsonNoether_charZero` and `JacobsonNoether_charP`. Instead, always use the proof of `JacobsonNoether_charP` but use `ExpChar` instead. The [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) is stated using `ExpChar`, hence unifies char 0 and char p case. In the char 0 case its `ExpChar` is 1, which makes your proof of `JacobsonNoether_charP` still works for char 0 case.

> I mean you don't need to separate the proof of `JacobsonNoether_charZero` and `JacobsonNoether_charP`. Instead, always use the proof of `JacobsonNoether_charP` but use `ExpChar` instead. The [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) is stated using `ExpChar`, hence unifies char 0 and char p case. In the char 0 case its `ExpChar` is 1, which makes your proof of `JacobsonNoether_charP` still works for char 0 case.

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

bot fix style
There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?

> There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?

I think indeed we've tried using [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) for Fact 2 in the blog. But like you said, we need to either extend purely inseparable to non-commutative case or figure out how to define `k(\alpha)` in the notation of that blog (the difficulty here is that `IntermediateField.adjoin` demands a field over `k(\alpha)`, which isn't easy to find). This is surely an interesting idea.
Sorry I didn't notice the change of `open Classical` in @Blackfeather007 's commit. It is indeed better to be placed behind.
I think instead of `open Classical`, the right thing to do is use tactic `Classical` whenever you need it

Do you think this is a better statement of the result?
```lean
import Mathlib.RingTheory.Algebraic
import Mathlib.FieldTheory.Separable

example {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D]
    [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
    (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
    (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
    âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
  sorry
```
~Note that this is not necessary correct; I haven't assume `k` is the center of `D`.~ The center assumption is needed, otherwise a couhterexample is `D` a (commutative) purely inseparable extension of `k`. ~But what about this: change the assumption to `Subalgebra.center k D â‰  âŠ¤` and the result to `âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subalgebra.center k D âˆ§ IsSeparable k x`?~

The advantage of this statement is that now `k` and `D` are both types, while your approach `k` is a subring, then converted to a type.

source.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(FieldTheory/{SeparableDegree|PurelyInseparable}): generalize some results on purely inseparable extension to non-commutative case

nodes.body:
> Do you think this is a better statement of the result?
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.RingTheory.Algebraic
> import Mathlib.FieldTheory.Separable
> 
> example {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D]
>     [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
>     (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
>     (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
>   sorry
> ```
> 
> ~Note that this is not necessary correct; I haven't assume `k` is the center of `D`.~ The center assumption is needed, otherwise a couhterexample is `D` a (commutative) purely inseparable extension of `k`. But what about this: change the assumption to `Subalgebra.center k D â‰  âŠ¤` and the result to `âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subalgebra.center k D âˆ§ IsSeparable k x`?
> 
> The advantage of this statement is that now `k` and `D` are both types, while your approach `k` is a subring, then converted to a type.

Then probly the assumption `hneq` is redundant since if âŠ¥ = âŠ¤ then not in âŠ¥ is in the empty set
Also it's probly not the best idea to use `rename_i`

> Do you think this is a better statement of the result?
> 
> ```lean
> import Mathlib.RingTheory.Algebraic
> import Mathlib.FieldTheory.Separable
> 
> example {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D]
>     [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
>     (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
>     (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
>     âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
>   sorry
> ```
> 
> ~Note that this is not necessary correct; I haven't assume `k` is the center of `D`.~ The center assumption is needed, otherwise a couhterexample is `D` a (commutative) purely inseparable extension of `k`. But what about this: change the assumption to `Subalgebra.center k D â‰  âŠ¤` and the result to `âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ Subalgebra.center k D âˆ§ IsSeparable k x`?
> 
> The advantage of this statement is that now `k` and `D` are both types, while your approach `k` is a subring, then converted to a type.

This is probably a good point; I would suggest that we try to keep *both* versions, provided the proof of the second is very very short using the first one.

OK, no problem: and thanks for the zulip name! Concerning the group chat, our hope is that everybody will be a regular active Zulip user, and private groups go a bit against this philosophy. I normally use DM with groups that I mentor, as in this case, but then the public chat is preferable.

This might not be a good commit and a recompilation is needed.
1. I moved `center_char_iff` to Algebra/CharP/Subring, this is a proof for characteristic of a division ring is equal to its center's. The reason for such move is that `subring` in Algebra/CharP/Subring gives a weaker but more general statement.
2. The instance `Algebra k D` is moved to Algebra/Algebra/Basic. I don't have any convincing argument in favour of this move - I just can't find other related file that works.

> > There is API for purely inseparable extension (unfortunately, only for commutative rings). Would you consider using it (after extend it to non-commutative case)?
> 
> I think indeed we've tried using [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/FieldTheory/PurelyInseparable.html#isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem) for Fact 2 in the blog. But like you said, we need to either extend purely inseparable to non-commutative case or figure out how to define `k(\alpha)` in the notation of that blog (the difficulty here is that `IntermediateField.adjoin` demands a field over `k(\alpha)`, which isn't easy to find). This is surely an interesting idea.

The newest version of mathlib supports purely inseparable for non-commutative rings. You can try it out.

> I think this is not needed, since the newly added instance has `{R : Type*}` which will override the existing `R`. 

Ah, you mean that in the new instance we do not want the `Comm`  assumption on  `R`?

> > I think this is not needed, since the newly added instance has `{R : Type*}` which will override the existing `R`.
> 
> Ah, you mean that in the new instance we do not want the `Comm` assumption on `R`?

I haven't checked the mathematics, but in the following code
```lean
variable [CommRing R]
variable (R)

...

instance {R : Type*} [Ring R] : ...
```
the code `instance {R : Type*} [Ring R]` will introduce a new `R` which is different from the existing `R` (you can check the info panel), so the original `[CommRing R]` is not carried over.

Greetings! In this commit, I added section `purelyInsep`, in which I tried to switch to `ExpChar` and purely inseparable. By such, `JacobsonNoether_charZero` and `JacobsonNoether_charP` are unified. 
~~However, I wasn't able to fill in the two `sorry` in `temp_exists_pow_mem_center_ofInseparable`, line 209. These two `sorry` are used to show that `Algebra.adjoin k {a}` (`k(a)` in the notation of the blog) is purely separable over `k`. The difficulties here are to prove `k(a)` is integral over `k`, and resolve the image of `algebraMap`.~~ Plus, I noticed that the new instance in LinearMaps seems to be slow.

> I wasn't able to fill in the two `sorry` in `temp_exists_pow_mem_center_ofInseparable`, line 209. These two `sorry` are used to show that `Algebra.adjoin k {a}` (`k(a)` in the notation of the blog) is purely separable over `k`. The difficulties here are to prove `k(a)` is integral over `k`, and resolve the image of `algebraMap`.

I don't think you need to tackle `Algebra.adjoin` things here, since they are already solved in separable/purely inseparable APIs. You may start with the following code:
```lean
import Mathlib.FieldTheory.PurelyInseparable

open LinearMap in
theorem test1
    {k D : Type*} [Field k] [DivisionRing D] [Algebra k D] [Algebra.IsAlgebraic k D]
    (hcenter : Subalgebra.center k D = âŠ¥)
    (hneq : (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) â‰  âŠ¤) :
    âˆƒ x : D, x âˆ‰ (âŠ¥ : Subalgebra k D) âˆ§ IsSeparable k x := by
  classical
  obtain âŸ¨q, _âŸ© := ExpChar.exists k
  by_contra! H
  have h1 : IsPurelyInseparable k D :=
    âŸ¨Algebra.IsAlgebraic.isIntegral, fun x â†¦ not_imp_not.1 (H x)âŸ©
  rw [isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem k q] at h1
  sorry
```
First you can conclude `IsPurelyInseparable k D` just from the definition of purely inseparable in mathlib. Then you use `isPurelyInseparable_iff_pow_mem` to conclude that every element of `D` can be powered into `k`.

The difficulties here are to prove `k(a)` is integral over `k`, and resolve the image of `algebraMap`.
